This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Figure 22: Data Dictionary help texts now available in SAP Fiori apps. Alt Text: The Manage Purchase Contracts screen is shown, with question marks next to all fields and column headers. On the right the Help Topics are listed, with the Purchase Contract Number selected. Next to the corresponding column header a popover shows the definition text.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse – but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting “Keyboard Shortcuts” in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Generic Keyboard Interactions”.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Journal Entries (43,854)”. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using “Cmd + D” to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time – magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The “Threshold” determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the “Scroll Threshold” determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “Configure Table” with two new fields “Threshold”, being edited with the value 3000, and “Scroll Threshold”, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or “Show more per row” State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if “show more per row” was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry “1710 (BestRun US)”, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is “BestRun US”. In the popover “Sort By” section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over “Column Settings” with two sections “Sort By” and “Group By”. The “Sort By” section has two lines, “Company Code” and “Company Name”, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing “no sorting”, “ascending”, “descending”.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “View Settings” containing tabs “Columns”, “Sort”, “Filter”, and a pop-over “Filters” with two options “Hide descriptions” (selected) and “Hide Unselected” (deselected) . “Columns” is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is “Company Code”, followed by “Created On” – i.e. the description column “Company Name” is not listed next to the “Company Code”.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what’s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What’s New Viewer:

  • What’s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The “Adapt UI” option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example “1710 (BestRun US)” as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example “US Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)” as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the “Export to Excel”, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called “Configure Table” filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as “Enable Table Export”, “Frozen Column Count” with a field for entering the number, “Sorting”, “Columns” etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits – now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP’s UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, … for Android, … for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

I’m also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: it’s a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card “Building Blocks” at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that “Choose Your Option” heading above two side-by-side cards for “Floorplans” and “Customer Layout”, each with an image and description, and a “Learn More” button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I’m looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd – Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading 😊 Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let’s be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company’s workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI – to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn’t it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism 😊 Guessing the comments like, “that is not for productive environment”, “DGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses” and many other sharp negatives. But let’s move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I’ve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post 😊 What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails 😊

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again “what is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!”. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You’ve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail 😊. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let’s implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order’s header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes it’s not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Let’s look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection don’t have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see  How to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in the Review Availability Check Result app, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see  Supply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand can’t get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC can’t get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isn’t exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity can’t get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesn’t have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and there’s also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer can’t order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isn’t possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection – Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, it’s possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldn’t make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be “losers”, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there won’t be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesn’t have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP

entry.title: S/4 Procurement for Public Sector: Purchasing Profiles: A Concise Overview
entry.content:
What Is a Purchasing Profile?

A Purchasing Profile is a structured container of organizational, accounting, and process data assigned to purchasing personas (purchaser, requestor, contracting officer). It centralizes shared attributes so users do not repeatedly search, re-enter, or manually maintain foundational data. It also isolates role-relevant information, reducing noise in day-to-day tasks.

Why It Matters

Without profiles, every purchasing action (request, order, contract) requires manual selection of entities like company code, cost center, purchasing org. data, or accounting information. Profiles let the system derive these automatically, letting users focus on true differentiators (item, supplier choice, terms).

Key Personas

  • Purchaser: Executes ordering.
  • Requestor: Initiates demand; minimal commercial adjustment.
  • Contracting Officer: Manages contractual frameworks and compliance.

A business configurator (or administrator) sets up profiles centrally instead of each persona maintaining their own settings.

How Profiles Work

Each profile bundles attributes (organizational units, accounting defaults, category controls, workflow indicators). These are referenced when creating purchasing objects (purchase requisitions, orders, contracts). Missing values can be overridden only where necessary.

Core Benefits

  • Reduced data entry and errors
  • Faster document creation
  • Consistent compliance posture
  • Centralized maintenance
  • Clear separation of role context

Inheritance Model

Profiles support hierarchical inheritance: child profiles extend parent attributes. This reduces duplication:

  • Define common data once (e.g., legal entity, currency).
  • Specialize at lower levels (e.g., category restrictions).
    Attributes can be:
  • Excluded: explicitly removed so they do not propagate further.
  • Overridden: replaced with a new value.
  • Marked as default: preferred value when multiple candidates exist.

Exclusions and Defaults

Exclusion flags stop an attribute from flowing down the inheritance chain. Default flags resolve ambiguity when more than one candidate attribute could apply.

Flexible Hierarchy

No rigid tree structure is imposed. You can design a model aligned to:

  • Geography
  • Business unit
  • Spend category
  • Project or program
    This flexibility supports gradual evolution without full redesign.

Implementation Tips

  1. Inventory common purchasing data elements.
  2. Start with a base (global) profile.
  3. Add layers only where differentiation is justified.
  4. Use exclusions sparingly; prefer consolidation.
  5. Audit default flags to avoid silent conflicts.
  6. Document profile intent for each layer.

Summary

Purchasing Profiles streamline creation of purchasing documents by centralizing and inheriting key data across personas. They reduce maintenance effort, improve consistency, and allow flexible structuring without enforcing a rigid hierarchy. Proper setup enables purchasing users to concentrate on value-added decisions rather than repetitive data handling.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit: Adapt the XML file to your business needs
entry.content:
When using the staging approach for your data migration, you often face the challenge that the provided XML file contains sheets and columns within the sheets that are not relevant for your business needs.

Did you know that it is possible to adjust the XML files easily?

However, before I go to the possible options, note that you must be careful when deleting, as any change can corrupt the XML structure. There is also no guarantee that such a tailored XML file can still be used after upgrading to a higher release.

After creating a migration project in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit using the Migrate Your Data app select Download Template in Action for a specific migration object and choose File Type → XML file.

Note 

The description below is for Microsoft Excel. The procedure may differ when using another spreadsheet program than Microsoft Excel.

Option 1: Delete a non-mandatory sheet

Open the downloaded file and choose Enable Editing button. Select a non-mandatory sheet you want to delete – choose the context menu by clicking on your mouse and choose "Delete".

 Confirm on the follow up pop-up you want to delete.

Proceed in this way with all the non-mandatory sheets that you want to delete.

Note

You can only delete non-mandatory sheets and delete sheets even though the worksheet contains mandatory columns. This is because there is no need to fill the mandatory columns in the sheet with data if the sheet itself is not relevant for your project.

Option 2:  Delete a non-mandatory column within a sheet

First, you need to unprotect the sheet. So, you need to select a sheet where you want to delete one column or more columns – choose the context menu by clicking right on your mouse and select “Unprotect Sheet”.

Select the column(s) you want to delete – in my example all columns for Tax Calculation Brazil. Choose "Delete".

Note

Alternatively, you can go to File → Info → Protect Workbook area and click on Unprotect for the sheets you want to make changes on.

Save your changes. You can now fill your XML file as usual and load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit.

When you upload your data, the tool informs you that the Validation Completed with Warnings.  

To be able to view the messages, choose "Show Messages" you get a list of all messages occurred during Validation.

In this case, warnings are displayed because the fields deleted in the previous steps are missing from the sheet. 

 To load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit select your file and transfer the data via Actions → Transfer Data to Staging Tables.

 The instances will be loaded into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit staging tables.

You can now proceed with your data migration steps as usual.

 Using CSV files

Like the XML file, you can easily tailor your CSV files  as you only need to use the files for the structures and fields you want to process. Just provide the files for mandatory structures and the structures you need. Within the files you must also only provide the mandatory fields and the fields you need. All the other fields you can remove.  A CSV file has much less administrative data than an XML file. The 100 MB limit is the same, but with tailored CSV files the http-protocol related size limit is not reached that fast as using XML files.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Replacing SAP Fiori apps during system conversion
entry.content:
SAP Fiori is the primary user experience of SAP S/4HANA.

So if you are already using SAP Fiori in the classic SAP Business Suite, the degree of change in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA can come as a surprise. The uplift in SAP Fiori can add an extra unexpected challenge to your system conversion.  In this post you will learn which decisions are needed and gain some suggestions on how to resolve them.

Hint: The classic SAP Business Suite includes SAP ECC, SAP Suite on HANA, SAP Simple Finance, SAP SRM, SAP GRC, and other solutions running on SAP NetWeaver.

These suggestions are collated from experiences of myself and my colleagues in the Early Adopter Care program for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and our SAP Customer Services & Delivery colleagues.

From our experiences across system conversion customers worldwide who are already using SAP Fiori in classic SAP Business Suite. These customers usually:

  •  Have deployed a limited number of SAP Fiori apps - usually less than 100 apps - in their classic SAP Business Suite environment. 
  • May be using SAP Fiori in a hybrid mode. For example, using SAP Fiori for employee self-service and manager self-service apps, and some targeted mobile apps, while SAP GUI is used for daily on-system tasks.
  • Want to take bring quick wins (aka immediate ROI) from the new/improved SAP Fiori launchpad features, and from the huge amount of predefined launchpad content available in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Even where the strategy is to move all users to the central launchpad – i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP Build Work Zone – you still need your local launchpad – i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad available on-stack in SAP S/4HANA – deployed as well.  The local launchpad is the target for content federation, and gives you access on-stack configuration, administration apps, and clean core extension apps.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core.

First the good news: Your change management journey is easier. 

Even though the SAP Fiori launchpad has changed, your users will recognize:

  • the overall look and feel of the launchpad,
  • some of the main launchpad features such as Settings, Search, and Notifications
  • know generally how to work with tiles, links and apps.

Your target user experience: the SAP Fiori launchpad My Home page as it appears in SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Now for the work ahead!

Start by listing all your existing SAP Fiori apps, custom-built apps, partner-built apps, and any custom-built launchpad features.  A simple spreadsheet will do.

Hint: Do your best to capture the SAP Fiori app id for apps delivered by SAP.  You can use the app id to find successor apps.

When doing a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA:

  • You will need to decide which of your existing apps and launchpad features to retain, replace, or discard. 
  • You may need to adjust custom-built apps and custom-built launchpad features, such as launchpad plug-ins.
  • This includes partner-built apps and launchpad features that you are using.

In this blog post you will learn:

  • Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors
  • Retain your custom-built Fiori apps
  • Verify partner-built Fiori apps you have deployed
  • Review your launchpad feature usage for successors
  • Remember your administrators
  • Watchpoints when coming from SAP Fiori in Enterprise Portal
  • Reintroducing your upgraded launchpad to your business users
  • Learnings to get you started
  • Background information: What’s behind the changes in SAP Fiori

Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors

Expect that most of the predefined SAP Fiori apps you are using in SAP Business Suite (SAP ECC) will need to be replaced.

Of the 836 SAP Fiori apps provided for the classic SAP Business Suite, only 248 of these are supported in SAP S/4HANA 2025. That’s less than 30%. Of those 248 apps:

  • 3 apps are deprecated and should not be used
  • 20 apps are available with successor, so you should use the successor
  • 11 are reuse apps that provide sub-features and are not available as tiles
  • 27 are industry-specific (mostly IS-OIL and IS-HER) and not relevant to most customers
  • 69 are relevant only to SAP GRC
  • 12 are relevant to SAP HCM compatibility pack – and are replaced by successors when moving to SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA

Leaving only 106 apps generally available, or about 12% of apps.

Hint: You can test this for yourself in the SAP Fiori apps reference library, downloading your list of apps and running them through the Upgrade Impact Analysis against your target SAP S/4HANA release. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Impact Analysis.

At most customers, the only app that is retained is SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox.

Hint: If you are currently using app F0862 My Inbox, you should consider with your system conversion:

  • Adding SAP Fiori app F6511 My Outbox to all users who have My Inbox.  My Outbox is a predefined app in SAP S/4HANA that reuses the same configuration as My Inbox. My Outbox provides self-service answers such as: Where is that workflow now? Who is the next approver? Is that workflow complete?
  • You may also want to consider adding the unified inbox across cloud solutions - SAP Task Center - which can be deployed with SAP Build Work Zone on desktop, and with SAP Mobile Start on mobile devices.

Most other apps will need to be replaced by successors.

 

General advice about successor apps

Sometimes there are obvious successors.

  • Successor apps can look and behave very differently to your current app. You will need to deploy the successor app to explore it.
  • Successor apps often have improved clean core compliant extension options. You will need to learn clean core techniques, such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, and Adapt UI.
  • If you have extended your existing SAP Fiori app, you will need to review your extensions, decide if the extensions are still needed, and if needed, reapply them using clean core compliant techniques.

Sometimes there are no successors.

For example, where the functionality has been moved to a SAP Cloud solution.

Where there are no successors, you will need to consider your options, such as:

  • Deploy the successor SAP Cloud solution
  • Replace with a custom-built app
  • Revert to a classic UI – such as SAP GUI, Web Dynpro application, or WebClient UI

Hint: If the classic UI works but is simply too busy for your users, or missing some defaults / tips, you can make some easy improvements with SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas is the Adapt UI for classic GUI transactions. There is no additional subscription needed for SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas flavors can be easily applied to existing launchpad content using the Launchpad App Manager – Adaptation Mode to add the parameter for the Personas Flavor.

Refer to:

  • SAP Help – SAP Screen Personas
  • How to use SAP Screen Personas with SAP Fiori Launchpad
  • SAP Fiori app F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas

Adapt UI for GUI Transactions in SAP S/4HANA 2025 launches SAP Screen Personas flavor maintenance for the app

These are predictable patterns you can use:

  1. Review Related Apps in the SAP Fiori apps reference library
  2. Approve apps become My Inbox sub apps
  3. HCM apps move to SAP SuccessFactors and/or SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA
  4. SRM apps move to Ariba or to Procurement

  6. Predictive Model apps move to Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)
  7. Factsheet apps move to SAP Fiori elements Object Page
